raw_text:
German growth goes into reverse
 
 Germany's economy shrank 0.2% in the last three months of 2004, upsetting hopes of a sustained recovery.
 
 The figures confounded hopes of a 0.2% expansion in the fourth quarter in Europe's biggest economy. The Federal Statistics Office said growth for the whole of 2004 was 1.6%, after a year of contraction in 2003, down from an earlier estimate of 1.7%. It said growth in the third quarter had been zero, putting the economy at a standstill from July onward. Germany has been reliant on exports to get its economy back on track, as unemployment of more than five million and impending cuts to welfare mean German consumers have kept their money to themselves. Major companies including Volkswagen, DaimlerChrysler and Siemens have spent much of 2004 in tough talks with unions about trimming jobs and costs. According to the statistics office, Destatis, rising exports were outweighed in the fourth quarter by the continuing weakness of domestic demand.
 
 But the relentless rise in the value of the euro last year has also hit the competitiveness of German products overseas. The effect has been to depress prospects for the 12-nation eurozone as a whole, as well as Germany. Eurozone interest rates are at 2%, but senior officials at the rate-setting European Central Bank are beginning to talk about the threat of inflation, prompting fears that interest rates may rise. The ECB's mandate is to fight rising prices by boosting interest rates - and that could further threaten Germany's hopes of recovery.
llama3.2:1b: Germany's economy shrank 0.2% in 2004, ending a year of contraction, with growth estimated at 1.6%. It was the fourth quarter of the year, down from an earlier estimate of 1.7%, and followed zero growth in the third quarter. The economic slowdown is attributed to Germany's reliance on exports, high unemployment (over five million), and impending cuts to welfare.
llama3.2:3b: Germany's economy shrank 0.2% in the last three months of 2004, with growth for the whole year at 1.6%. Exports drove the economy, but domestic demand remained weak. The rise in euro value has depressed competitiveness and raised interest rates, threatening Germany's recovery prospects.
gemma2:2b: German economy shrank 0.2% in the last three months of 2004, contradicting forecasts for a rebound. Exports have been key to economic recovery but domestic demand remains weak due to unemployment and welfare cuts, causing a standstill from July onwards. The value of the euro rose significantly, hurting German competitiveness abroad. This has impacted the Eurozone as a whole, with ECB officials now considering rate hikes to combat inflation, which could hinder Germany's recovery.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
German economy shrinks 0.2% in the last three months of 2004.

The Federal Statistics Office states growth for the whole of 2004 was 1.6%, after a year of contraction in 2003, but has fallen to zero this quarter. German consumers have kept their money at home as they are dependent on exports and unemployment are still high. Major companies including Volkswagen, DaimlerChrysler and Siemens have been negotiating with unions about cuts. While the value of the euro has risen, it also hurts Germany's competitiveness in the 12-nation eurozone and overall economy.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Germany's economy contracted 0.2% in Q4 2004 after a year of contraction last year, leading forecasts for the fourth quarter's growth of 0.2%. However, the strong euro has hurt German exports, which have not yet fully recovered despite increased imports. The rising value of the euro has also threatened inflation concerns and potential interest rate hikes by the ECB, potentially hindering Germany's economic recovery efforts.
qwen2.5:3b: German economy shrank 0.2% in last three months of 2004, disappointing post-contraction hopes. GDP growth for 2004 was 1.6%, after a year-long decline in 2003. Third quarter saw zero growth, putting economy on hold since July. Exports were offset by weak domestic demand. Rising euro value has hurt German competitiveness abroad, affecting eurozone and Germany's prospects. ECB interest rates at 2% but may rise due to inflation concerns, posing risk to recovery.
opencoder:1.5b: Germany's growth has gone into reverse in the last three months of 2004, upsetting hopes of a sustained recovery. The figures were manipulated in the fourth quarter of Europe's biggest economy. The Federal Statistics Office reported growth for the whole of 2004 as 1.6% after a year of contraction in 2003. The increase was down from an earlier estimate of 1.7%. The economy had been at a standstill from July onward, and Germany has been reliant on exports to stay ahead of unemployment. Major companies including Volkswagen, DaimlerChrysler and Siemens have made significant strides in terms of economic negotiation over the years. According to the statistics office, continuing weak points in exports have outweighed domestic demand in the fourth quarter.
smollm:1.7b: The summary should be: Germany's economy shrunk 0.2% in the last three months of 2004, upsetting hopes of a sustained recovery. The Federal Statistics Office said growth for the whole of 2004 was 1.6%, after a year of contraction in 2003, down from an earlier estimate of 1.7%. It said growth in the third quarter had been zero, putting the economy at a standstill from July onward. Germany has been reliant on exports to get its economy back on track, as unemployment of more than five million and impending cuts to welfare mean German consumers have kept their money to themselves. Major companies including Volkswagen, DaimlerChrysler and Siemens have spent much of 2004 in tough talks with unions about trimming jobs and costs. According to the statistics office, Destatis, rising exports were outweighed in the fourth quarter by the continuing weakness of domestic demand. The effect has been to depress prospects for the 12-nation eurozone as a whole, as well as Germany. Eurozone interest rates are at 2%, but senior officials at the rate-setting European Central Bank are beginning to talk about the threat of inflation, prompting fears that interest rates may rise. The ECB's mandate is to fight rising prices by boosting interest rates - and that could further threaten Germany's hopes of recovery.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about German economic performance in 2004. Let me read through it carefully.

The first sentence says Germany's economy shrank by 0.2% over the last three months, which is a significant drop. The article points out that this doesn't help with Europe's big recovery plan because they're still hoping for a similar expansion as before. 

Next, the Federal Statistics Office gives some numbers: growth was 1.6% overall in 2004, but it went down to zero in the third quarter. That means they were stuck at a standstill from July until December. Unemployment and welfare cuts are making consumers keep their money, which makes sense why exports were still so strong.

Major companies like Volkswagen, DaimlerChrysler, and Siemens are talking about cutting jobs and costs with unions. This shows the struggle for employment in Germany, which is part of their efforts to get back on track after last year's recovery that failed because they didn't have enough workers or jobs lost due to cuts.

 export values were still rising, but the article says it was outweighed by the weakness in domestic demand. So the economy wasn't expanding as much as hoped, even though exports are up. This explains why some European countries are worried about the Eurozone's prospects being affected by this.

The article mentions that the euro's value has gone up, which is making German products less competitive internationally. Since Germany's currency is stronger, their exports aren't as valuable there. Additionally, the ECB is pushing for higher interest rates to control inflation and push back on Germany's hopes of recovery. The ECB's main goal was to fight rising prices but this could be a double-edged sword because if rates go up more than expected, it might make things worse.

Putting it all together, I need to capture that Germany had a tough year with low growth, high unemployment, strong exports not keeping pace due to lower demand, companies struggling with costs, and the current economic environment is causing fears about recovery. The ECB's actions are both trying to fix the economy but also worrying about inflation.
</think>

Germany's 2004 economic performance was challenging with a drop in GDP of 0.2%, despite overall growth of 1.6%. Unemployment and welfare cuts kept consumer money held, causing a standstill from July onward. Major companies were under pressure to trim jobs and costs, while exports remained strong but insufficient to offset rising demand. The weak Euro made German products less competitive in the Eurozone, which is now worried about potential inflation due to ECB's efforts to raise interest rates.
tinyllama:1.1b: Germany's economy has seen a reversal in growth with a decrease in the quarterly expansion of 0.2%, leading to an overall decline of -0.2% for 2004 as reported by the Federal Statistics Office. The figures are down from an earlier estimate of +1.6%. Exports have been a source of stability for Germany's economy, but major companies including Volkswagen, DaimlerChrysler, and Siemens have continued to cut jobs and costs amid growing unemployment. Overall prospects for the eurozone as a whole are being threatened by higher Eurozone interest rates, while the ECB's mandate is to fight rising prices by boosting interest rates further.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Germany's economic growth in 2004 was significantly negative, as the country's economy contracted for the first time in a decade. In fact, the economy shrank by 0.2% during the last three months of 2004. This sharp decline in growth is causing major concern among experts, who predict that Germany may face further challenges if it cannot overcome its issues related to unemployment and stagnating domestic demand.

Germany's economic troubles are primarily attributed to the rise in the value of the euro last year, which has hit the competitiveness of German products overseas. This influx of euros has led to a weakening of Germany's domestic demand as consumers have been unable to spend as much money on goods and services due to the economic slump. Additionally, the European Central Bank is considering raising interest rates in response to concerns about inflation, which could further deteriorate Germany's prospects for recovery.

Germany's economy was once regarded as an engine of growth and prosperity for Europe, but its recent decline has left it at a crossroads as experts discuss whether the country can overcome these obstacles and regain its position as a global economic power.
phi:2.7b: The German economy shrank 0.2% in the last three months of 2004, disappointing expectations for sustained growth. Germany's reliance on exports has not helped its economy recover, as consumers have kept their money to themselves. Major companies are making cuts to maintain profitability. The value of the euro has made German products less competitive, which is affecting Europe and Germany as a whole. The European Central Bank may raise interest rates to fight inflation, which could hurt Germany's chances for recovery.
orca-mini:3b: Germany's economy shrank 0.2% in the last three months of 2004, upsetting hopes of a sustained recovery. The Federal Statistics Office said growth for the whole of 2004 was 1.6%, after a year of contraction in 2003, down from an earlier estimate of 1.7%. It said growth in the third quarter had been zero, putting the economy at a standstill from July onward. Germany has been reliant on exports to get its economy back on track, as unemployment of more than five million and impending cuts to welfare mean German consumers have kept their money to themselves. Major companies including Volkswagen, DaimlerChrysler and Siemens have spent much of 2004 in tough talks with unions about trimming jobs and costs. The effect of the euro's rise last year has hit the competitiveness of German products overseas, depressing prospects for the 12-nation eurozone as a whole, as well as Germany. Eurozone interest rates are at 2%, but senior officials at the rate-setting European Central Bank are beginning to talk about the threat of inflation, prompting fears that interest rates may rise. The ECB's mandate is to fight rising prices by boosting interest rates - and that could further threaten Germany's hopes of recovery.
hermes3:3b: Germany economic growth negatively, 0.2% drop in Q4 of 2004; 1.6% growth for 2004, down from earlier estimate.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Germany's economy contracted 0.2% in the last three months of 2004, contrary to expectations of a sustained recovery. Growth for the whole of 2004 was 1.6%, down from an earlier estimate of 1.7%. The Federal Statistics Office reported that growth in the third quarter had been zero, causing a standstill in Germany's economy from July onwards. This is due to export dependence and domestic demand weakness. However, rising euro value has also impacted German product competitiveness and affected the eurozone's overall prospects. The European Central Bank's mandate is to fight inflation, which could rise interest rates and further threaten Germany's recovery hopes.
stablelm2:1.6b: Germany's economy contracted by 0.2% in Q4, despite initial expectations for a slight expansion. This reverses the positive outlook on sustained recovery. Key factors contributing to this contraction include reliance on exports, high unemployment, and ongoing cost-cutting measures at major companies. Domestic demand continues to lag, with rising value of the euro affecting German competitiveness overseas. The effect is particularly evident in the eurozone as a whole, as well as Germany, where interest rates are currently at 2%. Rising interest rates could further hinder Germany's recovery prospects.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Germany's economy experienced a contraction in Q4 2004, with a 0.2% decline after initially forecasting expansion at 0.2%. The Federal Statistics Office revised 2004 growth to 1.6%, still below the 1.7% estimate from earlier. Germany's economy stagnated from July due to zero third-quarter growth, a consequence of consumers' cautious spending and employers' cost-cutting measures with unions. Despite robust exports, domestic demand's weakness overshadowed export gains. The strong euro reduced the competitiveness of German products abroad, impacting the broader 12-nation eurozone negatively. This devaluation also heightened inflation concerns among European Central Bank officials, potentially leading to rate hikes and posing a threat to Germany's recovery prospects.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Germany's economy contracted by 0.2% in the last quarter of 2004, dashing hopes of a recovery. Annual growth for 2004 was revised down to 1.6% after stagnation in the third quarter. The economy relied on exports, as high unemployment and welfare cuts curbed consumer spending. Major firms like Volkswagen and Siemens negotiated job and cost cuts. However, weak domestic demand and the euro's strength hurt exports, impacting both Germany and the eurozone. Concerns over inflation may lead the European Central Bank to raise interest rates, further threatening Germany's recovery.
reference: The figures confounded hopes of a 0.2% expansion in the fourth quarter in Europe's biggest economy.Germany's economy shrank 0.2% in the last three months of 2004, upsetting hopes of a sustained recovery.The ECB's mandate is to fight rising prices by boosting interest rates - and that could further threaten Germany's hopes of recovery.It said growth in the third quarter had been zero, putting the economy at a standstill from July onward.Germany has been reliant on exports to get its economy back on track, as unemployment of more than five million and impending cuts to welfare mean German consumers have kept their money to themselves.
